etymologies: mid 19th century. From post-classical Latin bonitarius, either from classical Latin bonus good + -itārius (in e.g. hērēditārius), or from classical Latin bonitās good quality + -ārius, in either case with reference to classical Latin in bonīs esse, in bonīs habere to have beneficial possession without formal legal title

definitions: Having or relating to the right to the use or benefit of property without formal legal title.
